revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox military person |honorific_prefix=''SS-[[Standartenführer]]'' |name=Helmuth Raithel |image= Helmuth Raithel.jpg |alt=Helmuth Raithel wearing ''Waffen-SS'' uniform |caption=Raithel as an ''[[Obersturmbannführer|SS-Obersturmbannführer]]'' |birth_date={{birth date|1907|04|09|df=y}} |death_date={{death date and age|1990|9|12|1907|04|09|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Ingolstadt]], [[Bavaria]], [[German Empire]] |death_place= |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= |placeofburial_coordinates= |nickname= |allegiance= {{Flagicon|Germany}} [[Weimar Republic]] (to 1933)
{{flagicon|Nazi Germany}} [[Nazi Germany]] |branch={{plainlist | * {{flagicon|Weimar Republic}} ''[[Reichswehr]]'' * [[File:Balkenkreuz.svg|18px|link=]] ''[[Wehrmacht]]'' * [[File:Flag Schutzstaffel.svg|23px]] ''[[Waffen-SS]]'' }} |serviceyears=1926–45 |rank=''[[Standartenführer|SS-Standartenführer]]'' |unit={{plainlist | * [[6th Mountain Division (Wehrmacht)|6th ''Gebirgs'' Division]] (1940–42) * [[13th Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Handschar (1st Croatian)|13th ''Waffen'' Mountain Division of the SS ''Handschar'' (1st Croatian)]] (1943–44) * [[6th SS Mountain Division Nord|6th SS Mountain Division ''Nord'']] (1944–45) }} |commands= [[23rd Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Kama (2nd Croatian)|23rd ''Waffen'' Mountain Division of the SS ''Kama'' (2nd Croatian)]]. |battles={{plainlist | * [[Battle of Greece]] * [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] * [[World War II in Yugoslavia]] * [[Western Front (World War II)|Western Front]] }} |battle_label= |awards={{flagicon image|Blutorder.gif}} [[Blood Order]]
{{flagicon image|DEU DK Gold BAR.png}} [[German Cross|German Cross in Gold]]
{{flagicon image|DEU EK 1 Klasse BAR.svg}} [[Iron Cross|Iron Cross 1st Class]] |spouse= |relations= |laterwork=Agriculture
Mountaineering}} '''Helmuth Raithel''' (9 April 1907{{spaced ndash}}12 September 1990) was a [[Nazi Germany|German]] officer who held the rank of ''[[Standartenführer|SS-Standartenführer]]'' (colonel) in the ''[[Waffen-SS]]'' during [[World War II]]. While still at school, Raithel was swept up in the excitement of the [[Munich]] [[Beer Hall Putsch]] of 9 November 1923 led by [[Adolf Hitler]], and was subsequently awarded the coveted [[Blood Order]], even though he was not a member of the [[Nazi Party]]. He joined the ''[[Reichswehr]]'' (interwar German Army) in 1926. After World War II broke out he fought in the [[Battle of Greece|invasion of Greece]] in summer 1941, then against the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Red Army]] in northern [[Finland]] before transferring to the ''Waffen-SS'' in 1943. Raithel subsequently commanded a regiment of the newly formed [[13th Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Handschar (1st Croatian)|13th ''Waffen'' Mountain Division of the SS ''Handschar'' (1st Croatian)]] and led it during fighting against the [[Yugoslav Partisans]] in the [[Independent State of Croatia]]. Raithel was seriously wounded in mid-1944 and was replaced. When a new ''Waffen-SS'' division was to be raised in June 1944, the [[en cadre|cadre]] was provided by the 13th SS Division and Raithel was appointed as the divisional commander. The [[23rd Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Kama (2nd Croatian)|23rd ''Waffen'' Mountain Division of the SS ''Kama'' (2nd Croatian)]] never reached full divisional strength and did not see action as a formation, but elements of the division fought briefly in southern Hungary in early October 1944. Raithel quickly suppressed a mutiny by the [[Bosniak|Bosnian Muslim]] soldiers of the division in mid-October 1944, but it was disbanded and its reliable troops were absorbed by the 13th SS Division and the [[31st SS Volunteer Grenadier Division]]. Raithel was then appointed to command a regiment of [[6th SS Mountain Division Nord|6th SS Mountain Division ''Nord'']] in [[Alsace]], where his regiment fought the [[United States Army]]. He received a serious head wound during fighting northeast of [[Frankfurt]] in early April 1945 and was captured by the Americans. Raithel recovered from his wounds and had a career in agriculture after the war, working in [[South Africa]] for many years. He returned to [[Bavaria]] when he retired and earned a doctorate of history from the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|University of Munich]]. His interest in mountaineering continued and he regularly climbed in the [[Alps]] into his seventies. He maintained contact with his former comrades from the 6th SS Division, attending many reunions. On 12 September 1990 at the age of 82, he was returning home from the [[Semmering Pass]] in eastern Austria when he was killed in a traffic accident. ==Early life== Born Helmuth Hans Walter Paul Raithel in [[Ingolstadt]], [[Kingdom of Bavaria]], a [[federated state]] of the [[German Empire]], on 9 April 1907, he was the second son of a [[Bavarian Army]] officer. Raithel attended [[Volksschule|primary school]] then the ''[[Wittelsbacher-Gymnasium München]]'' (secondary school) until 1926. On 9 November 1923 at the age of 16, Raithel was walking his bicycle in [[Munich]] when he stumbled across the [[Beer Hall Putsch]] being led by [[Adolf Hitler]]. Swept up in the excitement, he fell in with a group led by ''[[Freikorps]]'' veteran [[Gerhard Roßbach]]. After shots were fired, he took cover with some of the group in an alley, one of whom wrote down Raithel's name as one of the "party faithful" present that day. He was subsequently awarded the highly prized [[Nazi Party]] [[Blood Order]], although he apparently did not have any political beliefs and was not a member of the Party at the time.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=38}}{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} After he successfully completed secondary school in early 1926, he joined the ''[[Reichswehr]]'' as a ''[[cadet|offizieranwärter]]'' (officer cadet) on 1 April 1926. He was posted to the 19th Infantry Regiment during which he spent four years commanding a ''[[Gebirgsjäger]]'' (mountain infantry) [[platoon]]. While he was with the regiment, the ''Reichswehr'' was absorbed by the ''[[Wehrmacht]]''. Now part of the ''Gebirgs Brigade'', Raithel gained experience as a signals officer and company commander, and was promoted to ''[[Hauptmann]]'' (captain). With the creation of the [[1st Mountain Division (Wehrmacht)|1st ''Gebirgs'' Division]] in April 1938 he was appointed as the [[adjutant]] of the 99th ''Gebirgsjäger'' Regiment. At the outbreak of war in September 1939 he was an instructor at the mountain infantry school at [[Fulpmes]] in the [[Stubai Alps]].{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=38}}{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} He was married and he and his wife had two daughters.{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} ==World War II== ===Greece and Finland=== In August 1940, Raithel was transferred from instructional duties to command a battalion of the newly formed [[6th Mountain Division (Wehrmacht)|6th ''Gebirgs'' Division]], which had been deployed to France on occupation duty in anticipation of involvement in the planned invasion of the [[United Kingdom]], [[Operation Sealion]]. When Sealion was abandoned, the division was sent first to [[Poland]] then in spring 1941 took part in the [[Battle of Greece|invasion of Greece]].{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=39}} During the [[Battle of Metaxas Line]] in early April 1941, the division, led by ''[[Generalmajor]]'' (Brigadier) [[Ferdinand Schörner]], breached the formidable Greek defences by crossing a {{convert|2100|m|ft|adj=on}} snow-covered mountain pass considered inaccessible by the Greeks. This enabled the division to cut the rail line to [[Thessaloniki]].{{sfn|Blau|1986|p=88}} Raithel was awarded the [[Iron Cross|Iron Cross 1st Class]] in late April 1941. Following the defeat of Greece and its allies, the division was deployed to [[Lapland (Finland)|Lapland]] in northern [[Finland]] in September 1941. Raithel remained as a battalion commander with the 143rd ''Gebirgsjäger'' Regiment of the division in Finland and was promoted to ''[[Major]]'' on 1 November 1941.{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} Schörner became Raithel's mentor during their service with the 6th ''Gebirgs'' Division.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=39}} In January 1942 he was awarded the [[German Cross in Gold]]. In August 1942 he was transferred to the ''[[Oberkommando des Heeres]]'' (Army Headquarters) reserve pool for an extended period, during which he returned to the mountain infantry school then served briefly with the [[133rd Fortress Division (Wehrmacht)|133rd Fortress Division]] on [[Crete]]. He was promoted to ''[[Oberstleutnant]]'' (lieutenant colonel) on 1 October 1943.{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} ===Yugoslavia=== [[File:Handzar.PNG|thumb|260px|13th SS Division's area of responsibility with the NDH (in green).{{sfn|Lepre|1997|pp=143–145}}|alt=a map of the NDH highlighting an area in the eastern part of Bosnia where the division operated]] In 1943, his mentor Schörner, now a ''[[General der Gebirgstruppe]]'' (lieutenant general), advised him to transfer to the quickly expanding ''[[Waffen-SS]]'' where regimental command would be easier to come by, particularly as his Blood Order was especially prized in the ''Waffen-SS''.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=39}} Raithel subsequently transferred to the ''Waffen-SS'' (and ''[[Allgemeine SS]]'') on 30 November 1943, but still did not join the Nazi Party.{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} He was immediately appointed to command a regiment of the newly formed [[13th Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Handschar (1st Croatian)|13th ''Waffen'' Mountain Division of the SS ''Handschar'' (1st Croatian)]], the [[wikt:rank and file|rank-and-file]] of which were mostly [[Bosniaks|Bosnian Muslims]]. Initially appointed as an ''[[Obersturmbannführer|SS-Obersturmbannführer]]'' (lieutenant colonel) commanding the 28th ''Waffen Gebirgsjäger'' Regiment, he oversaw the completion of his regiment's training at the [[Świętoszów|Neuhammer]] training grounds in the [[Silesia]]n region of Germany (present-day Poland) then led his regiment to fight the [[Yugoslav Partisans]] in the [[Independent State of Croatia]] (NDH) in February 1944. The division was given the primary role of securing around {{convert|6000|km2}} of territory (the designated security zone) in north-eastern [[Bosnia (region)|Bosnia]] within the NDH. The security zone encompassed the [[Posavje Great Parish|Posavina]], [[Semberija]] and [[Majevica]] regions between the [[Sava]], [[Bosna (river)|Bosna]], [[Drina]] and [[Spreča]] rivers. ''[[Reichsführer-SS]]'' [[Heinrich Himmler]] saw this task as critical to the safeguarding of important agricultural areas and ''[[Volksdeutsche]]'' (ethnic German) settlements in the [[Syrmia]] region to the north.{{sfn|Lepre|1997|pp=143–145}} Between March and June 1944 Raithel commanded his regiment during several major operations, including what may have been the largest anti-Partisan sweep of the war, [[13th Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Handschar (1st Croatian)#Anti-Partisan operations March to May 1944|Operation ''Maibaum'']] (Maypole).{{sfn|Lepre|1997|p=187}} He was promoted to ''[[Standartenführer|SS-Standartenführer]]'' (colonel) on 1 April 1944.{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} Raithel led his regiment well, resulting in a serious wound in June 1944.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=39}} On 11 June 1944, he was recommended for an award of the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross]] citing his leadership and courage while commanding the regiment, but it was not approved.{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} While it achieved successes and proved itself competent in counter-insurgency operations against the Partisans in eastern Bosnia between March and August 1944,{{sfn|Bishop|2007|pp=137–138}} the 13th SS Division earned a reputation for brutality and savagery, not only during combat operations,{{sfn|Tomasevich|2001|p=499}} but also through atrocities committed against Serb civilians in the security zone.{{sfn|Williamson|2004|p=123}}{{sfn|Keegan|1970|p=105}} When a second Bosnian Muslim ''Waffen-SS'' division was to be raised in June 1944, the [[en cadre|cadre]] was provided by the 13th SS Division and Raithel was appointed as the divisional commander.{{sfn|Lepre|1997|p=228}} The [[23rd Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Kama (2nd Croatian)|23rd ''Waffen'' Mountain Division of the SS ''Kama'' (2nd Croatian)]] never reached full divisional strength and did not see action as a formation, but elements of the division fought briefly in southern Hungary in early October 1944.{{sfn|Lepre|1997|p=263}} The Bosnian Muslim members of the division mutinied on 17 October 1944, but Raithel quickly gained control over the situation. Following the mutiny, the division was formally disbanded on 31 October and reliable elements were absorbed by the 13th SS Division and the [[31st SS Volunteer Grenadier Division]].{{sfn|Lepre|1997|p=266}} ===Germany=== After a short time convalescing as part of the ''[[SS Führungshauptamt]]'' (SS headquarters) reserve pool, Raithel was appointed to command the 11th ''Gebirgsjäger'' Regiment of the [[6th SS Mountain Division Nord|6th SS Mountain Division ''Nord'']] in December 1944. In early January 1945, the division was located around [[Pirmasens]] near the French-Reich border, reeling from their losses in what was the last major German offensive of World War II on the [[Western Front (World War II)|Western Front]], [[Operation Nordwind|Operation ''Nordwind'']].{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=39}} Committed to a series of desperate [[counterattack]]s against the [[United States Army]] [[XV Corps (United States)|XV Corps]], on one occasion Raithel's regiment infiltrated the American positions, surrounding five US infantry companies and taking 450 [[prisoner of war|prisoners of war]]. The fighting depleted the already understrength regiment, with one company numbering only eight men by 20 January. The commander of one of the US battalions they fought in January 1945 ruefully described Raithel's regiment as, "the best men we ever ran into, extremely aggressive, and impossible to capture. There was no driving them out, for they fought until they were killed".{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|pp=39–42}} After a quiet period in February 1945 absorbing replacements, the division was withdrawn from the defensive line and ordered to recapture [[Trier]] from the US Army. This attack started on 7 March in freezing conditions but after limited success a fresh US offensive struck the division and forced them back north of [[Mainz]]. By 19 March, Raithel's regiment had been converted into a ''[[kampfgruppe]]'' (battlegroup) consisting of two ''gebirgsjäger'' battalions, a mountain artillery battalion, a pioneer company and eight anti-tank guns.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=71}} Two weeks later they were fighting their way out of encirclement near [[Limburg an der Lahn|Limburg]].{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=85}} On 1 April 1945, ''Kampfgruppe'' Raithel and the rest of what remained of the division drove east. Shortly afterwards, Raithel received a serious head wound and was captured.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=301}} The remnants of the division disintegrated over the next few days and weeks and were captured by the Americans.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=339}} ==Personal life== Raithel recovered from his wounds and had a career in agriculture after the war, working in [[South Africa]] for many years. He returned to Bavaria when he retired and earned a doctorate of history from the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|University of Munich]]. He continued with mountaineering and regularly climbed in the [[Alps]] into his seventies. He maintained contact with his former comrades from the 6th SS Division ''Nord'' and attended many reunions. On 12 September 1990 at the age of 82, he was returning home from the [[Semmering Pass]] in eastern Austria when he was killed in a traffic accident.{{sfn|Rusiecki|2011|p=340}} ==Career== Raithel received the following promotions during his career, after joining the ''Reichswehr'' as an officer cadet on 1 April 1926:{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} ===''Reichswehr''=== * ''[[Leutnant]]'' - 1 June 1930 * ''[[Oberleutnant]]'' - 1 July 1932 ===''Wehrmacht''=== * ''[[Hauptmann]]'' - 1 April 1937 * ''[[Major]]'' - 1 November 1941 * ''[[Oberstleutnant]]'' - 1 October 1943 ===''Waffen-SS''=== * ''[[Obersturmbannführer|SS-Obersturmbannführer]]'' - 1 December 1943 * ''[[Standartenführer|SS-Standartenführer]]'' - 2 April 1944 ==Awards== Raithel received the following awards during his service:{{sfn|Yerger|1999|p=37}} * [[German Cross|German Cross in Gold]]{{sfn|Patzwall|Scherzer|2001|p=365}} * [[Iron Cross|Iron Cross First Class]] * [[Infantry Assault Badge]] * [[Eastern Front Medal]] * [[Order of Bravery|Order of Bravery (Fourth Grade, First Class)]] ([[Kingdom of Bulgaria]]) ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book | last1 = Bishop | first1 = Chris | title = Waffen-SS Divisions, 1939–45 | year = 2007 | publisher = Amber Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-905704-55-2 | ref = harv }} * {{cite book | last=Blau | first=George E. | title=The German Campaigns in the Balkans (Spring 1941) | url= | origyear=1953 | year=1986 | publisher=United States Army Center of Military History | edition= Reissue | location=Washington, DC | id=CMH Pub 104-4 | oclc=16940402 | ref=harv }} * {{cite book | last = Keegan | first = John | authorlink = John Keegan | title = Waffen SS: The Asphalt Soldiers | year = 1970 | publisher = Pan/Ballantine | location = London | isbn = 978-0-345-09768-2 | ref = harv }} * {{cite book | last = Lepre | first = George | title = Himmler's Bosnian Division: The Waffen-SS Handschar Division 1943–1945 | year = 1997 | publisher = Schiffer Publishing | location = Atglen, PA | isbn = 978-0-7643-0134-6 | ref = harv }} * {{Cite book |last1=Patzwall |first1=Klaus D. |last2=Scherzer |first2=Veit |year=2001 |title=Das Deutsche Kreuz 1941 – 1945 Geschichte und Inhaber Band II |trans_title=The German Cross 1941 – 1945 History and Recipients Volume 2 |language=German |location=Norderstedt, Germany |publisher=Verlag Klaus D. Patzwall |isbn=978-3-931533-45-8 |ref = harv }} * {{cite book | last = Rusiecki | first = Stephen | title = In Final Defense of the Reich: The Destruction of the 6th SS Mountain Division "Nord" | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xCoTjyrLTM8C | year = 2011 | publisher = Naval Institute Press | location = Annapolis, MD | isbn = 978-1-59114-744-2 | ref = harv }} * {{cite book | last = Tomasevich | first = Jozo | author-link = Jozo Tomasevich | title = War and Revolution in Yugoslavia, 1941–1945: Occupation and Collaboration | url = https://books.google.com/?id=fqUSGevFe5MC | volume = 2 | year = 2001 | publisher = Stanford University Press | location = San Francisco | isbn = 978-0-8047-3615-2 | ref = harv }} * {{cite book | last = Yerger | first = Mark C. | title = Waffen-SS Commanders: The Army, Corps and Divisional Leaders of a Legend : Kruger to Zimmermann | url = | year = 1999 | publisher = Schiffer Publishing | location = Atglen, PA | isbn = 978-0-7643-0769-0 | ref = harv }} * {{cite book | last = Williamson | first = Gordon | title = The SS: Hitler's Instrument Of Terror | url = https://books.google.com/?id=7gv7yPIdQdsC | year = 2004 | publisher = Zenith Press | location = St Paul | isbn = 978-0-7603-1933-8 | ref = harv }} {{refend}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Raithel, Helmuth}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:People from Ingolstadt]] [[Category:People from the Kingdom of Bavaria]] [[Category:Recipients of the Gold German Cross]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Bravery]] [[Category:Recipients of the Blood Order]] [[Category:Yugoslavia in World War II]] [[Category:Greece in World War II]] [[Category:SS-Standartenführer]] [[Category:Reichswehr personnel]] [[Category:Gebirgsjäger of World War II]] [[Category:Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich alumni]] [[Category:Collaborators who participated in the Beer Hall Putsch]] [[Category:German expatriates in South Africa]]
